player.seasonOutlook: Injuries derailed his 2018 and put a stop to a promising three-year workload growth pattern. Bookending what were three disabled list stints ? for latissimus, oblique and shoulder issues ? was an eight-start, season-opening stretch during which time he had a 1.62 ERA and 1.08 WHIP, and a 15-appearance, season-concluding span during which he had a 1.47 ERA and 1.20 WHIP and ultimately captured the team's closer role. Those stretches illustrated that he still has the capability to be a front-line fantasy option regardless of role, and the Cardinals do intend to have him in their rotation again at the onset of 2019. Martinez now carries enough risk to be picked outside of the top 25 starting pitchers rather than within it, but there's always the chance that with a little luck, he could finally reach that tier.

Familia topped 70 innings for the fourth time in five seasons in 2018, racking up 17 saves for the Mets before a midseason trade to Oakland. His strikeout rate jumped after the deal (11.5 K/9) and the A's altered his fastball mix by having him throw more four-seamers and fewer two-seamers, but his slider continues to generate most of his whiffs. After becoming a free agent for the first time in his career this offseason, Familia returned to the Mets on a three-year, $30 million deal. Interestingly enough, he chose to re-sign with his old club after they acquired Edwin Diaz from Seattle, which likely puts Familia in a setup role unless the Mets elect to mix and match their late-inning arms and forgo the use of a traditional closer. Without regular save opportunities, Familia doesn't miss enough bats or post ratios good enough to offer much value, outside of leagues that value holds.

Morrow pitched well in his first season with the Cubs, posting a career-low 1.47 ERA en route to 22 saves, before being placed on the DL with right biceps inflammation in mid-July. A series of setbacks eventually led to a decision to shut him down for good in September, at which point the injury was called a bone bruise. In November, Morrow had arthroscopic surgery on his right elbow, and while the procedure was referred to as a cleanup, he will not begin throwing until February at the earliest and is expected to miss at least the first month of the regular season. Morrow's strikeout and swinging-strike rate dropped last season as the Cubs reduced the use of his slider and cutter, perhaps in an effort to keep him healthy. His injury history likely limits him to a traditional closer role when he's able to pitch, as it's unlikely that he would be asked to get more than three outs on a regular basis. Pedro Strop is the favorite to open the season as the Cubs' closer in Morrow's absence.

After starting only 49 combined games from 2016-2017, Keuchel tied teammate Justin Verlander with an AL-leading 34 starts last season. His 204.2 innings were the seventh most in the majors. However, his already-pedestrian strikeout rate fell to 17.5 percent, the lowest mark since that of his rookie season. The southpaw maintained excellent control and kept the ball in the yard, but a low strikeout total hurts his fantasy potential. The drop in strikeouts was supported by a dip in swinging-strike rate, also its nadir since Keuchel's freshman campaign. For the past several seasons, Keuchel has benefited from Minute Maid Park, stealthily one of the top pitching venues in the game. Keuchel can still be a fantasy asset, but he needs to be backed by solid infield defense, as an extreme groundball rate remains his bread and butter.

Smith made a stunning recovery from Tommy John surgery last season, showing the same high-strikeout, split-proof performance he did before going under the knife. But this time he added much better control, evidenced by a 7.1 percent walk rate. His success was so distinct that it pushed him into the San Francisco Giants' closer conversation after only two months' and 25 appearances' worth of work, where he went 14-of-17 in save chances and probably earned "favorite" honors in the team's ninth-inning competition this spring. Smith's final-month struggles, perhaps caused by fatigue, do cast a hint of doubt upon his ability to hold up as an elite fantasy closer for a full 162-game schedule, but if he can stay on the mound, he has a skill set that's borderline top-10-worthy at the position. Among the midrange closer hopefuls, he's one of the more intriguing choices.

Bradley endured a 2018 of adjustments, at one point having to ease off the use of his curveball due to it increasing the chances of cracking the nail on his forefinger, at another ramping up the usage of his sinker, and at another shuffling between multi-inning and short reliever across different stages of the game. In retrospect, it's perhaps understandable why he never emerged as the Arizona Diamondbacks' closer, though he certainly possesses the stuff to do it should the team choose him in the future. Bradley strangely struggled against right-handed hitters in 2018, as they batted .272/.314/.481 against him, so he'll need to address that if he's to capture a ninth-inning role and develop into a top-line fantasy closer. But even if he's again the primary eighth-inning guy, something that seems likely with Greg Holland now on board, Bradley should contribute useful ratios and a good strikeout total in leagues that reward middle relievers.

While it might seem counterintuitive considering what we know about Yankee Stadium's homer-friendly ways, Happ's return to the New York Yankees this offseason might've been the best thing for his fantasy prospects. Following his trade to the Yankees last July 26, he was one of the better starters in the game, going 7-0 with a 2.69 ERA and 1.05 WHIP in 11 starts. While those numbers shouldn't be extrapolated across a full season and assumed to repeat, the Yankees coaxed the best from Happ, recognizing that his four-seam fastball, which has registered near-93-mph average velocity for five years straight, was his key to success. That plan probably won't change, and while his stuff isn't necessarily good enough to capture Cy Young votes, it does make him one of the most reliable, underrated starters in fantasy. Don't let him slip too far in your draft, as he's a valuable middle-of-your-staff type.

Betances' stuff is filthy and generates plenty of swings and misses, and to that point, in 2018, he became the first relief pitcher in baseball history to strike out at least 100 batters in five consecutive seasons. He has been one of the most reliable setup men in baseball, and with it fantasy baseball, during that time frame, albeit with a couple of late-season blips sprinkled in when he seemed to lose the feel for his slider (see: 2016, 2017). The New York Yankees have done a much better job keeping his workload reasonable in the past two years, too, and he rewarded them with a 2.84 ERA, 41.0 percent strikeout rate and 6.7 percent walk rate after the All-Star break last season, strengthening his chances of a 2019 repeat. While Betances probably won't get many save chances, in a bullpen full of closer-capable relievers, he's one of the best options out there for ERA, WHIP and K's.

Hamels' 2018 was a tale of two seasons. He spent the first four months with the Rangers, posting the worst ratios of his career (4.72 ERA, 1.37 WHIP) but with a strikeout rate that recovered from a dismal 2017 (6.4 K/9) offering a glimmer of hope after the Cubs acquired him in July. A slight uptick in velocity and an increased reliance on his four-seam fastball, paired with an escape from a hitter-friendly home park accompanied a huge stretch run, as he posted a 2.36 ERA and 1.10 WHIP over his 12 starts with Chicago. After the trade, Hamels' home run rate dropped, as his HR/FB was nearly cut in half to 10.9 percent. The Cubs picked up Hamels' $20 million option for 2019 in November, and he appears to have the tools necessary to be the team's best starting pitcher this season, thanks to an excellent changeup and a very good curveball that still induce plenty of whiffs.

The casual fan will look at Lester's 2018 campaign and see an ace. However, the truth is Lester pitched worse than the previous season, when his ERA was a run higher, in line with 2018's major ERA estimators. The southpaw's 19.6 percent strikeout rate was the lowest since the same mark in 2013, and his 8.4 percent walk rate was the highest since 2011. A fortunate strand rate kept Lester's ERA in check. If he repeats the same peripherals, Lester is looking at an ERA in the mid-4.00 range. Pitchwise, Lester's velocity and usage were like the previous campaign's, but his fly ball rate rose to 36.4 percent, the highest since 2014, contributing to 1.19 HR/9, well above his career 0.88 level. With a declining strikeout rate and with him not going as deep into games, Lester is reliant on ratios to drive value, a very risky proposition.

Archer has carved out quite a career for himself as an "elite underlying skills, but ordinary rotisserie numbers" pitcher: He is the first pitcher in the history of baseball to record as many as three separate campaigns of at least 25 starts and a 25 percent strikeout rate, but also an ERA of 4.00 or more, and his three have all come in consecutive years from 2016-18. Part of the problem is that he possesses an elite slider -- which explains the strikeouts -- but his other offerings just haven't made the cut, though that screams "faulty command" more than anything. One can only wonder whether his being pitted with pitching coach/guru Ray Searage might pay bigger dividends for Archer in 2019, though after so many years of disappointment, fantasy managers might understandably be hesitant to trust him. The K's alone make Archer a top-40 starter candidate, and there's always the chance he could finally raise the performance bar with a National League team and in a pitching-friendly home ballpark.

An Achilles injury had a lasting impact upon his performance all of last season, and while the New York Yankees saw enough in Britton to trade for him in July, his 2.88 ERA and 1.16 WHIP in 25 regular-season appearances for them were still a far cry from his dominating 2014-16 years. He continued to generate ground balls with the best of them, with a rate greater than 70 percent, but while his average fastball velocity rebounded to a degree in pinstripes, it still fell about a full mph shy of his past rates. Britton returned to the Yankees on a multiyear deal during the winter, where he'll spend the bulk of his time in a setup capacity, meaning he'll have greater value in leagues that reward holds. He's a useful source of ERA, WHIP and strikeouts but would need a lights-out spring to be considered one of the top setup options out there.

Gausman has long been hailed a fantasy breakthrough candidate, but it wasn't until his July trade to the Atlanta Braves that he finally seemed to realize his position. In 10 starts for them, he had five wins, five quality starts, a 2.87 ERA and 1.14 WHIP, though he did so at considerable expense to his strikeout rate (18.2 percent, compared to 21.2 for his career). Increased sinker usage partly explained the improvement, but that's an adjustment that might lock in said lower K rate in exchange for more ground balls, meaning Gausman might've simply spun his wheels in terms of fantasy appeal. To that point, here are his career FIPs working forward: 3.99, 3.41, 4.10, 4.10, 4.48, 4.32. He's plenty capable of a top-50 fantasy starter season, but consider anything more icing on the cake.

Darvish might enter the 2019 season the greatest risk/reward candidate among pitchers. He has long been a high-strikeout type, his 28.6 percent K rate the past three years combined ninth-best amongst 120 qualifiers, but has made five trips to the disabled list during that time span alone, for elbow, shoulder, back, and triceps issues, and the flu -- oh my! Following a minor September surgery to clean up debris in his right elbow, Darvish claims he should be fully healthy come spring training, which puts him in position to make a run at the top 25 fantasy starting pitchers again, health willing. He'll warrant careful attention throughout February and March, with the most pertinent question being whether he has reined in the control issues he exhibited in his eight starts of 2018, during which he had an 11.7 percent walk rate. With Darvish, it's often about how lucky you're feeling.

Porcello had a rough 2017, when he was held back by a bloated .324 BABIP. The veteran rebounded well, though he was victimized again, this time by a low strand rate. Porcello's actual 4.28 ERA was about half a run higher than his 3.87 xFIP and the 3.77 mark SIERA predicted. His 1.18 WHIP was the second lowest in his career, bested only by his Cy Young campaign. Porcello's 99 starts the past three seasons were second only to Justin Verlander's 101. However, Porcello fell short of the 200-inning plateau for the first time since 2015. Despite making changes to combat his proclivity for the long ball, Porcello's 1.27 HR/9 was still well above average. The mantra is not to chase wins. However, durable pitchers on high-scoring teams are in a better position to earn victories. Porcello is not flashy, but that keeps the cost reasonable.

After a year-and-a-half detour through Texas, Jeffress returned to the Milwaukee Brewers in late 2017, and his previous dominance for the Brew Crew returned last season. While he was extraordinarily fortunate relative to his skill set, evidenced by a .250 BABIP (.310 for his career) and 92.9 left-on-base percentage (80.3 percent career), his career-best 29.8 percent strikeout rate coupled with a 58.2 percent ground-ball rate showed that he indeed recaptured his prior closer-worthy form. Jeffress' ratios are bound to worsen slightly in 2019, but he'll be a candidate for saves in the Brewers' loaded bullpen when the season dawns, making him one of the more interesting speculative relief picks, even in mixed leagues. Consider him a top-30 option at the position, even without the firm promise of save chances.

Freeland's was one of 2018's most unexpected success stories, and that he managed a fourth-place finish in the National League Cy Young voting as well as a top-10 big league ranking in terms of WAR as a Colorado Rockies pitcher was nothing short of remarkable. To that point, his 2.85 overall ERA was second-best in franchise history, trailing only Marvin Freeman's 2.80 in 1984, during which he worked only 112 2/3 innings, and his 2.40 ERA at Coors set a new franchise mark. Now for the bad news: Freeland's 82.8 left on base percentage says he's bound to regress in the ERA department in 2019, and he got a lot of advantageous calls that threatens his numbers across the board if he doesn't get the same breaks, as he had a major league-leading 139 strikes on pitches thrown outside the zone. Even with his five-pitch mix that's above-average at minimizing hard contact, he's still closer to a matchups type than one to lock in as a repeat top-25 fantasy starting pitcher. Roll him back about 20-25 spots and you're adjusting appropriately for inevitable regression, though he can still help you despite being a Rockies pitcher.

Alvarado was by far the Tampa Bay Rays' most effective relief pitcher last season, and since the team lacks an obvious choice for the ninth inning, he has to be considered the odds-on favorite to get the bulk of their save chances. His sinker/slider/curveball combination makes him a top candidate for strikeouts and ground balls, and he only seemed to show more polish as 2018 progressed, posting a 2.10 ERA, 0.94 WHIP and 37.6 percent strikeout rate in 29 second-half appearances. That Alvarado was so dominant against right-handed hitters -- .163/.262/.233 rates allowed -- only affirms his candidacy to close despite his left-handedness. The Rays do like to mix and match in all pitching roles, which will inevitably cap any individual's number of save chances, but Alvarado's odds of a healthy number of them make him a bona fide top-20 fantasy reliever option.

Walks might always be the obstacle standing in Newcomb's path to greatness. While he seemed to be improving in that department during the first half of 2018, posting a 2.71 ERA in 16 starts in the Atlanta Braves' first 81 team games behind a 10.6 percent walk rate, he gave back many of those gains thereafter, his ERA ballooning to 5.45 and walk rate to 12.9 percent in his final 15 turns (one of them a relief appearance). While fatigue might've been a factor in his decline, Newcomb needs to work on getting strike one if he's truly to make a push for the upper tiers of the fantasy starting pitcher pool. He seems to be the type who capitalizes upon the matchups, as it's worth tucking away that he was 8-0 with a 1.47 ERA against sub-.500 teams last season, but that paints the picture of more of a deep-mixed and NL-only target than something more. Don't get carried away.

Injuries held Miller back for the majority of 2018, as he made trips to the disabled list for hamstring, knee and shoulder issues, and he failed to pitch 60-plus innings or post a sub-1 WHIP for the first time in five years. The St. Louis Cardinals chose to regard his 2014-17 as closer to his true value than last year's stat line, though, signing him to a two-year, $27.5 million deal this winter. He'll serve as one of their late-inning options, in a bullpen that seems likely to lean on in-game matchups rather than defined roles, so Miller could sniff a good number of save chances that would help in his quest to rebound. His control remains good and his strikeout rate didn't completely fall of a cliff in 2018, so it's a worthwhile gamble on their part and would be for a prospective fantasy manager, too, though understand that at 34 years old he'll again be a heightened injury risk.

Dominguez's high-90s fastball and biting slider were extremely difficult for opposing hitters to read during his rookie season, evidenced by his beginning his big-league career with 12 consecutive scoreless outings, and finishing the year with a 32.0 percent strikeout rate and .156 batting average allowed (seventh-best among qualified relievers). Hitters did begin to catch up and his control slipped, however, as he posted a 4.81 ERA and 15.0 percent walk rate in 25 second-half appearances that suggested he still has adjustments yet to make. Dominguez probably won't have to work in quite as many high-leverage spots as he did in 2018, which could be good for him, and he should be able to help in ERA and strikeouts in leagues that value setup relievers. Assuming he can rein in the walks, he'll be a top candidate for holds.

Quintana's numbers in 2017 after being sent up the Red Line from the White Sox to the Cubs had many excited for a big 2018 that never materialized. His ratios were below average thanks to a higher-than-normal walk rate and a reduction in his strikeout rate, yet solid run support allowed him to win 13 contests. Quintana's problems centered around being left in games too long. His ERA jumped from 2.97 to 3.59 to 7.15 with each turn through a lineup. Opponents hit .329 against him, and he had an abysmal 5.0 K-BB% the third time through a lineup. Quintana's workload has come down with the switch to the National League, but it needs to come down further to allow him to avoid the overexposure to lineups that badly impacted his overall numbers in 2018. Quintana had no such troubles in 2017, but he has every other year.

Gonzales, once a top prospect with the St. Louis Cardinals, finally broke through as a member of the Seattle Mariners in 2018, at a stage in his career where he had almost entirely been written off for fantasy purposes. Thanks to the addition of a cutter as well as significantly greater usage of his curveball, he posted 12 wins, 12 quality starts, a 3.37 ERA and 1.16 WHIP through his first 21 starts of the season. Gonzales cooled to the tune of a 5.93 ERA thereafter, his increased workload -- his 166 2/3 innings were only 43 fewer than he had in 2015-17 combined -- a likely explanation. Far better control, as his 4.7 percent walk rate was a professional best, gives him an excellent chance at a repeat, or better, a step forward in 2019. Gonzales was a top-50 starter last year, and warrants consideration in that tier again on draft day.

The Baltimore Orioles' midseason fire sale finally spun the closer carousel around to Givens come last August, where the steady three-year performer managed to convert 8-of-10 save chances with a 2.25 ERA in the season's final two months. Good fortune played a part, as he had a .121 BABIP during that same time span, and that his walk rate from 2016-18 combined was a mere 9.6 percent suggests a potentially bumpy road ahead. Givens did have a 3.37 ERA, 1.17 WHIP and 27.8 percent strikeout rate the past three years combined, and those might be reasonable expectations for him again in 2019. The problem is that those don't reflect the performance of a typical, top-shelf closer, meaning that you're paying at least as much for his role itself as his talent. Givens should probably be drafted among the bottom third of the 30 projected big-league closers.

Vizcaino looks on track to open the year as the Braves' closer, a role his 2.11 ERA from last season would say he deserves. His underlying numbers, however, suggest that he's not particularly likely to remain in the job. Vizcaino's FIP trailed his ERA by a considerable margin, coming in at 3.76, and his xFIP (which heavily regresses HR/FB numbers) came in at a thoroughly unremarkable 4.21 for the second straight season. Some pitchers can consistently outperform their peripherals by generating weak contact, but Vizcaino's hard contact rate of 35.6 percent sat right around league average. He'll have value for as long as he's getting saves, but don't buy Vizcaino at a price which requires him to be the primary closer in Atlanta for the entire season.

One of the most frustrating pitchers to roster in fantasy, granted in large part due to his being a member of the Colorado Rockies, Gray couldn't have had a much more inconsistent past-three-year span. His ERA varied by nearly a run and a half between 2017 and 2018, and most strangely, he was a more effective starter at Coors (4.30 ERA, 1.25 WHIP) than away from it (4.83/1.36), a strange truth considering his reliance upon his breaking pitches. Gray continues to post strong skills metrics, including well-above-average strikeout and ground ball rates, so there's no reason to completely avoid him despite the nightmare that was his 2018. He still possesses the ability to provide top-50 fantasy starter numbers if everything clicks, and the good news is that he might not even carry that high a price tag after his past struggles.

The Cubs leaned on Strop as the primary option to close out games after Brandon Morrow went on the shelf, and he finished with a career-high 13 saves in 2018 while posting a sub-3.00 ERA for the fifth straight season. Underneath the uptick in fantasy value, Strop posted his lowest strikeout rate since 2012 (23.8 percent), and hitters were able to put the ball in the air against him more frequently, snapping a four-year stretch in which he maintained a ground ball rate above 50 percent (46.1). Strop's ratios are at risk if he's unable to slow his declining strikeout rate. However, since Morrow is expected to miss at least the first month of the season, Strop is the favorite to open 2019 as the Cubs' closer and see plenty of save chances until Morrow is ready to return.

Teheran did not take kindly to the move from Turner Field to SunTrust Park in 2017, as he was blasted to the tune of a 5.86 home ERA. Last season, that came down nearly two full runs, and his other statistics once again began to resemble the numbers he put up while pitching on the south side of town. Teheran has historically been tough on righties, and he held them to a career-low .182 average last season, but he did allow 15 of his 26 homers to righties. His overall numbers, however, are troublesome. He had a sub-4.00 ERA in spite of a high walk rate and high home run rate, thanks in large part to a BABIP that was more than 50 points below his career norm. StatCast data and FIP tell us his 2018 could have been much worse, and the 2019 projections show the same. There is more risk than reward to deal with here.

The hardest-throwing pitcher in baseball last season -- both his four-seam fastball and sinker averaged greater than 100 mph -- Hicks got a shockingly low number of swings and misses considering the power in his game, posting a 20.7 percent strikeout rate. His game was centered more on minimizing hard contact and generating ground balls, a recipe that would be fine and closer-worthy if not for so-so control, evidenced by his 13.3 percent walk rate. Regardless, Hicks seems like the logical favorite to close for the St. Louis Cardinals, making him a top-30 worthy fantasy relief pitcher. He'll need to make some improvements to his command in order to register a greater finish to 2019 than that, so keep an eye on his progress during spring training.

Bieber lacks top-shelf raw stuff, but he possesses some of the sharpest control in all of professional baseball. He had 19 walks total in 49 career minor league starts (plus one relief appearance) over a two-calendar-year span, which played a huge part in his advancing that quickly through the Cleveland Indians' system. Bieber then posted a 4.7 percent walk rate that ranked seventh-best and 67.3 percent strike rate that ranked ninth-best in the game from his May 31 big-league debut date forward. As a result of being so fine with his pitches, he did get hit hard at times, though his major league-high .356 BABIP during that same time suggests that he has quite a bit of room for growth nevertheless, especially armed with at least three and arguably four decent enough pitches. Bieber probably doesn't possess the ceiling of a fantasy superstar, an annual top-20 type at his position, but he's also one of the higher-statistical-floor youngsters out there, one you could probably get in the final rounds of your draft and keep locked into your staff all year.

Godley set career highs in wins, starts, innings and strikeouts in 2018, but little else went his way. A jump in walk rate as well as opponents' batting average led to a big jump in ERA and WHIP from 2017 to 2018. Godley's best pitch is his curveball, and he threw it 40 percent of the time in 2018, which helped him finish ninth in the National League in strikeouts. A large portion of Godley's troubles in 2018 came when he faced hitters for a third time in a game; he had a 9.20 ERA the third time through a lineup, allowing seven home runs, while batters hit .293/.382/.478 against him in those situations. Godley was much better in those situations in 2017, almost too good to believe, and the regression bit him hard in 2018. This is a case where less usage should lead to better results.

September 2017 shoulder surgery cost Rodon the first two months of last season and slowed him in his first five starts of the year, but for a brief period midseason he looked like the promising prospect he was in 2015-16. He tossed nine consecutive quality starts encompassing the entirety of July and August, his ERA 1.84 during that span, but his underlying numbers painted the picture of a wildly inconsistent hurler, his command pinpoint in one outing but shoddy the next. Rodon's sluggish finish to the year cast doubts upon the extent of his bounce-back potential entering 2019, as his average fastball velocity declined slightly in each of the past two seasons. He remains a good speculative late-round pick in mixed leagues, but would need to have a standout spring to warrant much more.

Arrieta's debut season in Philadelphia was decent, but the warning signs that led to him staying on the free-agent market as long as he did continued. His strikeout rate has declined each of the past five seasons, while his opponents' batting average and ERA worsened in each of the past four. A positive sign was that he ended a disturbing three-year decline in velocity, as each of his pitches saw a slight uptick in average velocity in 2018. He is still a groundball-heavy pitcher, but his misses now get his harder than they did in his heyday with the Cubs. He is no longer the ace that can go deep into a game (5.53 ERA the third time through an order), and should not be drafted as such. The quandary is whether he can decelerate this aging curve he is on and remain effective.

After consecutive seasons of five-plus ERA and sub-18 percent strikeout rates, Gibson finally provided his fantasy managers some production in 2018. Thanks to adding a hint of velocity to his four-seam fastball and sinker, as well as relying more upon his slider, his strikeout rate surged to a career-best (by far) 21.7 percent. Unfortunately, that's about where Gibson's gains stopped, as he regressed in that department during the season's second half (18.8 percent) and still has work to do in terms of his control. It's possible he could take another step forward in 2019, but more likely, he'll spin his wheels and/or be more of a streaming-starter type in fantasy mixed leagues.

All saves are not created equal. Greene saved 32 games, as did Brad Hand, but Greene's inferior ratios cost rotisserie teams in the end. Greene finished the 2017 season as closer, posting a 2.66 ERA. Coming into last year, an ERA correction was due, as 2017's SIERA pegged Greene at 4.02. Things reversed last year as Greene's 5.12 mark was well above the 3.57 estimated by SIERA. Greene's walk rate was 6.6 percent compared to 12 percent the previous season, however he allowed 12 homers, twice as many as 2017. Despite the bloated ERA, Greene held the closer role all year, and to be fair, his 4.05 ERA at the break wasn't terrible. Greene finished the campaign with a 6.94 mark, but heir apparent Joe Jimenez's 7.78 second-half ERA was even worse. Greene will likely begin the season as closer; don't plan on him ending it in that spot.

For the second consecutive season in 2018, Green managed a top-175 overall Player Rater finish while ranking among the league's top 300 in fantasy points, accomplishing that despite not recording a single save in either year. That's how elite his skill set is, highlighted by being one of the best in baseball at getting ahead in the count, as well as the only reliever in baseball to pitch at least 60 innings while striking out at least six times as many batters as he walked in both 2017 and 2018. Green has closer-worthy skills, and while he probably won't be the New York Yankees' first choice for the ninth inning -- and might be more like their sixth- or seventh-inning man -- he could be quite a helpful pitcher for ratios and K's even in mixed formats. And if he ever did move into a closer's role ? wow, what potential.

Coming off a horribly unlucky 2017, Pivetta broke through with a 3.26 ERA, 1.09 WHIP and 28.8 percent strikeout rate through last season's first two months, only to see that same misfortune strike him the remainder of the way. Lost was the substantial growth he exhibited with his curveball; he recorded 70 of his 188 strikeouts with that pitch, 12th most in the majors. That alone isn't enough to push Pivetta's ceiling into fantasy's elite, but it's important to point out that he has now ranked among the three "toughest luck" pitchers in terms of ERA/FIP differential in each of the past two seasons (minimum 130 innings pitched in each), so there's still growth potential here. Don't forget him as a back-of-your-staff type in mixed leagues, and consider him a potentially profitable middle-of-your-staff NL-only pick.

The favorite for saves in the Miami Marlins' bullpen as spring training dawned, Steckenrider is presumed to have that role thanks in large part to the 3.02 ERA he posted in his final 50 appearances last season. He has swing-and-miss stuff -- his strikeout rate in parts of two big league seasons is 30.3 percent -- but could stand to cut down on the walks and return to the ground balling ways he exhibited as a minor leaguer. The Marlins might not have many wins to nail down, and Steckenrider could be one of the more inconsistent finishers even if he emerges, but he's their smartest speculative bet.

Although Hill's late-career resurgence has been quite a story, it has come with the caveat of a great deal of risk for his fantasy managers; he has averaged 23 starts and 126 innings the past three seasons and has not exceeded 140 big league frames in a single campaign since 2007. Blisters have been especially problematic for him, as he has made six trips combined to the disabled list for them since the 2016 All-Star break, and his 39 years of age won't give him any greater odds of avoiding them in 2019. Fortunately, Hill's 3.03 ERA, 0.94 WHIP and 29.6 percent strikeout rate in 13 second-half starts -- plus staying healthy for its entirety -- eased any worry about his full-season rate regression, making him the same high-risk, high-reward player he has been since he joined the Los Angeles Dodgers. He won't give you the volume necessary to be a top-50 fantasy starter, but if your league allows maximum flexibility, he can be a pretty handy option when healthy.

Kela emerged as the Texas Rangers' closer at the onset of 2018, converting 24 of 25 save chances with a 3.44 ERA and 29.0 percent strikeout rate before the team traded him to the Pittsburgh Pirates at the deadline for prospect Taylor Hearn. After that, Kela exhibited similarly strong skills in setup relief; he had a 2.93 ERA and 36.7 percent K rate in 16 appearances, but with the same elevated walk rate (9.0 percent for the Pirates, 9.4 percent career) and fly ball tendency that make him slightly risky in the ratio categories. Kela is more valuable as handcuff material for Felipe Vazquez's fantasy managers, though his strikeouts can be valuable in NL-only formats.

Armed with a deceptive delivery and an above-average changeup, Lucchesi posted the third-most strikeouts among rookie starters last season (145). Unfortunately, a hip injury cost him more than a month's time, and as opponents began to become more familiar with him, he posted a 4.75 ERA while giving up 13 home runs in 14 starts after July 1. Lucchesi will probably need to make some adjustments to improve as a sophomore, particularly adding a pitch to neutralize right-handed hitters, who slugged .486 against him. He's still worth a speculative pick in deeper mixed leagues, though.

Heaney's recovery from July 2016 Tommy John surgery couldn't have gone much better than it did, as after a sluggish season-opening three starts he posted a 3.91 ERA, 1.17 WHIP and 6.0 percent walk rate in 27 starts from May 1 forward, resulting in his narrowly missing the top 50 fantasy starters come year's end. He added a hint of velocity to his sinker and posted one of the most effective changeups of any pitcher, with the biggest drawback being a 92-point wOBA lefty/righty split. Heaney could be ready to take the next step towards the top 40 fantasy starting pitchers, but his injury history makes it difficult to trust him as much more than a late-round mixed league pick.

The acquisition of Kelvin Herrera muddles the White Sox saves picture, as both he and Colome have closing experience and are on team-friendly contracts. Chances are at least one is moved at the deadline, with Herrera the more likely, giving Colome a minimum of a couple months worth of saves. Acquired by the White Sox from the Mariners last November, Colome has always racked up strikeouts while usually keeping the ball in the yard, aided by working in pitchers' parks. Guaranteed Rate Park suppresses runs, but it's generous for homers. Colome's year-to-year control has been inconsistent, with last season's walk rate right around his career average. Colome isn't a workhorse, but he's fairly durable. With the uncertain role, he's iffy in mixed leagues but could be a nice play in AL-only.

Injuries continued to curtail DeSclafani's development, though he did finish the season healthy. After missing the entire 2017 campaign with elbow woes, DeSclafani hurt his left oblique in spring training, delaying his 2018 debut until early June. While it's encouraging the issue wasn't arm related, DeSclafani suffered the same injury before the 2016 campaign. When on the hill, DeSclafani incurred a serious case of gopheritis, surrendering 24 homers in just 115 frames. His HR/FB ballooned to 19.8 percent, well above league average. While some regression is likely, DeSclafani needs to improve his location and sequencing, especially against left-handed batters. His velocity and K% ticked up a bit, though his swinging-strike rate remained the same. DeSclafani's 16.1 K-BB% last season plants a seed of optimism, but he needs to stay healthy and keep the ball in the yard. He should enter camp with a rotation spot that's his to lose.
